Posted By: BlackAlbino (5/7/2011 10:28:22 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
When I first saw her, I was angry, not just because I'm phyrexian, but because she only targets specific decks. I ***HATE*** things that target specific colors or decks like this.
  
then I realized
  
She can be used *with* infect
  
some have mentioned specific combos, but let me put it all together
  
First, shield you from backlash: [Ichor Rats](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ichor Rats ) and [Phyrexian vatmother](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Phyrexian vatmother).
  
Then, makes [Phyrexian Hydra](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Phyrexian Hydra) *invincible*   
then makes [black sun's zenith](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=black sun's zenith) a one sided board sweep
  
then, lets [Everlasting Torment](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Everlasting Torment) make you entire board as untouchable as your hydras
  
   
Yes, there is the persist angle, but that's actually a different story. With these as an infect deck, the flavor is hilarious, I call it "Melira's Hypocrasy"
  
Phyrexian hypocrasy is more accurate, but Melira's has a better ring
posts.html:
When I first saw her, I was angry, not just because I'm phyrexian, but because she only targets specific decks. I HATE things that target specific colors or decks like this.
then I realized
She can be used with infect
some have mentioned specific combos, but let me put it all together
First, shield you from backlash: Ichor Rats and Phyrexian vatmother.
Then, makes Phyrexian Hydra invincible
then makes black sun's zenith a one sided board sweep
then, lets Everlasting Torment make you entire board as untouchable as your hydras

Yes, there is the persist angle, but that's actually a different story. With these as an infect deck, the flavor is hilarious, I call it "Melira's Hypocrasy"
Phyrexian hypocrasy is more accurate, but Melira's has a better ring

posts.post_content:
Rule 112.6h  
http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg/daily/feature/141a&page=4  
  
*"This new addition to the list of rules explaining where abilities work says that if an object has an ability that says counters can't be placed on it, that ability functions while the object is entering the battlefield. "Placed" carries double duty, meaning adding counters while an object is on the battlefield and also having an object entering the battlefield with counters."*  
  
She doesn't just stop infect, and wither. She also *breaks Persist in half*, makes modular *worthless* if you are (for some reason) playing both of them, she also makes [Etched Monstrosity](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Etched Monstrosity) one hell of deal.
posts.html:
Rule 112.6h
http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg/daily/feature/141a&page=4

"This new addition to the list of rules explaining where abilities work says that if an object has an ability that says counters can't be placed on it, that ability functions while the object is entering the battlefield. "Placed" carries double duty, meaning adding counters while an object is on the battlefield and also having an object entering the battlefield with counters."

She doesn't just stop infect, and wither. She also breaks Persist in half, makes modular worthless if you are (for some reason) playing both of them, she also makes Etched Monstrosity one hell of deal.

posts.post_content:
In the right deck, this card is ridiculously broken! Look at the 2nd ability: Creatures you control can't have -1/-1 counters placed on them. So, with Devoted Druid, you get infinite green mana! With a persist creature and a sacrifice outlet of your choosing, you get infinite sacking!  
  
@garabor: I think you are right! If I assume that Melira operates similarly to tatterkite (for -1/-1 counters), Tatterkite has this ruling:   
5/1/2008 A spell or ability whose effect would put a counter on Tatterkite simply doesn't affect it. The spell or ability isn't countered. If it would put counters on any other creatures, it continues to do so.  
I misread the ruling, because the important part is "a spell or ability whose EFFECT would put a counter". Also, this ruling supports your statement:   
5/1/2008 You can't pay a cost that includes putting a counter on Tatterkite. For example, if Tatterkite is the only creature you control, you can't cast Scarscale Ritual because you can't pay the addition... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
In the right deck, this card is ridiculously broken! Look at the 2nd ability: Creatures you control can't have -1/-1 counters placed on them. So, with Devoted Druid, you get infinite green mana! With a persist creature and a sacrifice outlet of your choosing, you get infinite sacking!

@garabor: I think you are right! If I assume that Melira operates similarly to tatterkite (for -1/-1 counters), Tatterkite has this ruling:
5/1/2008 A spell or ability whose effect would put a counter on Tatterkite simply doesn't affect it. The spell or ability isn't countered. If it would put counters on any other creatures, it continues to do so.
I misread the ruling, because the important part is "a spell or ability whose EFFECT would put a counter". Also, this ruling supports your statement:
5/1/2008 You can't pay a cost that includes putting a counter on Tatterkite. For example, if Tatterkite is the only creature you control, you can't cast Scarscale Ritual because you can't pay the addition... (see all)

posts.post_content:
Let's see...  
-[Phyrexian Hydra](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Phyrexian Hydra) becomes a 7/7 infect for 5cmc [Cho-Manno, Revolutionary](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Cho-Manno, Revolutionary)  
-If you play this after [Carnifex Demon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Carnifex Demon), your creatures are fine! Just load him up with a [Skinrender](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Skinrender) beforehand  
-[Glistening Oil](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Glistening Oil ) becomes a reusable [phyresis](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=phyresis) w/ no drawback for you, or a slow and torturous reusable removal for your opponents  
-[Black Sun's Zenith](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Black Sun's Zenith) becomes a one sided board sweep  
-Invincibility combo with this and [Phyrexian Unlife](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Phyrexian Unlife) on the board  
-[Phyrexian Vatmother](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Phyrexian Vatmother) and [ichor rats](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=ichor rats) now have no drawback  
-[Etched Monstrosity](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Etched Monstrosity) is now a 10/10 for 5cmc w/ no drawback  
-This completely breaks the persist mechanic, not to mention your opponents will be effed if they are playing infect or wither.  
  
I know a lot of this was already mentioned, but I felt like summing up
posts.html:
Let's see...
-Phyrexian Hydra becomes a 7/7 infect for 5cmc Cho-Manno, Revolutionary
-If you play this after Carnifex Demon, your creatures are fine! Just load him up with a Skinrender beforehand
-Glistening Oil becomes a reusable phyresis w/ no drawback for you, or a slow and torturous reusable removal for your opponents
-Black Sun's Zenith becomes a one sided board sweep
-Invincibility combo with this and Phyrexian Unlife on the board
-Phyrexian Vatmother and ichor rats now have no drawback
-Etched Monstrosity is now a 10/10 for 5cmc w/ no drawback
-This completely breaks the persist mechanic, not to mention your opponents will be effed if they are playing infect or wither.

I know a lot of this was already mentioned, but I felt like summing up

posts.post_content:
Something else this helps hose: [Flourishing Defenses](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Flourishing Defenses)/[Everlasting Torment](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Everlasting Torment) decks which rely on damage field wipes to clear the way for their elves.   
  
Granted, you'll need a [Day of Judgement](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Day of Judgement) or [Infest](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Infest) or just a good ol' [Naturalize](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Naturalize) to get through their side, at least your side won't be blindsided by repeated Black Sun's Zenith type wipes.
posts.html:
Something else this helps hose: Flourishing Defenses/Everlasting Torment decks which rely on damage field wipes to clear the way for their elves.
